Drug Reaction with Eosinophilia and Systemic Symptoms (DRESS) Syndrome
Drug Reaction with Eosinophilia and Systemic Symptoms (DRESS Syndrome)

diagnoses.name: Streptococcal pharyngitis
diagnoses.description: A bacterial infection that can make your throat feel sore and scratchy. Often causes throat and oral erythema.

diagnoses.name: Erythema multiforme
diagnoses.description: An immune-mediated condition that involves the appearance of erythema or lesions on the skin and sometimes the lips and oral mucosa, occasionally associated with infections.

diagnoses.name: Iron deficiency anemia
diagnoses.description: A common type of anemia that can cause pallor and sometimes erythema in various body parts due to reduced iron intake or absorption.

diagnoses.name: Kawasaki disease
diagnoses.description: A condition that causes inflammation in the walls of some blood vessels in the body. It's characterized by fever, lip and oral erythema, and possibly anemia.

diagnoses.name: Glomerulonephritis
diagnoses.description: An inflammation of the tiny filters in your kidneys (glomeruli). Can lead to hematuria and pyuria, and sometimes anemia.

diagnoses.name: Urinary tract infection (UTI)
diagnoses.description: An infection in any part of the urinary system, kidneys, bladder, or urethra. Commonly presents with pyuria.

diagnoses.name: Aplastic anemia
diagnoses.description: A rare, life-threatening anemia where the body stops producing enough new blood cells, causing susceptibilities to infections that might present oral and pharyngeal erythema.

diagnoses.name: Sjögren's syndrome
diagnoses.description: An immune system disorder characterized by dry eyes and dry mouth, but can also lead to oropharyngeal erythema and systemic effects like anemia.

diagnoses.name: Scarlet fever
diagnoses.description: A bacterial illness that develops in some people who have strep throat. It's marked by a bright red rash on the body, with fever and redness in the oropharynx.

diagnoses.name: Systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE)
diagnoses.description: A systemic autoimmune disease that can affect many parts of the body, including the skin, joints, kidneys, blood cells (leading to anemia), and mucous membranes, causing erythema.

diagnoses: Drug reaction (including drug rash with eosinophilia and systemic symptoms [DRESS] syndrome)
Parvovirus B19 infection (erythema infectiosum or fifth disease)

Drug reaction with eosinophilia and systemic symptoms (DRESS) syndrome

Viral Infections (e.g., Dengue Fever, Zika Virus)
Schizophrenia (in the context of psychosis primarily, with other symptoms potentially being secondary or unrelated)
Acute lymphoblastic leukemia (for leukopenia, considering differential diagnosis)
Rickettsial Diseases (e.g., Rocky Mountain Spotted Fever)
Schizophrenia (in the context of autoimmune psychosis)
Infectious diseases (e.g., HIV, Hepatitis C, Secondary syphilis)
Hepatitis B or C (with renal involvement)
Sjögren's Syndrome with neurological and renal manifestations
Evans Syndrome (Autoimmune Hemolytic Anemia combined with ITP)
Hepatitis B or C with associated glomerulonephritis
Viral hepatitis (e.g., Hepatitis B, Hepatitis C)
Phrynoderma (Follicular Hyperkeratosis due to Vitamin A deficiency)
Viral Infections (e.g., Dengue Fever, Zika Virus)
Inflammatory Bowel Disease (e.g., Crohn's Disease, Ulcerative Colitis)
Vasculitis (e.g., Henoch-Schönlein purpura, Granulomatosis with polyangiitis)
Leukemia (e.g., Chronic Lymphocytic Leukemia - CLL or Acute Myeloid Leukemia - AML)

symptoms: dyspnea with normal pulmonary function tests

diagnoses.name: Systemic Lupus Erythematosus
diagnoses.reason: This autoimmune disease can cause a wide range of symptoms, including inflammation of various body tissues, which might lead to symptoms like leukocytosis and difficulty focusing vision.

diagnoses.name: Churg-Strauss Syndrome
diagnoses.reason: Also known as eosinophilic granulomatosis with polyangiitis, it can lead to asthma-like symptoms (e.g., wheezing), sinusitis, and peripheral neuropathy which could be associated with vision problems.

diagnoses.name: Goodpasture's Syndrome
diagnoses.reason: This autoimmune disease that attacks the lungs and kidneys could potentially lead to hematuria (could be misinterpreted as or exacerbate interstitial cystitis symptoms), difficulty breathing (wheezing), and sometimes kidney problems can cause leukocytosis.

diagnoses.name: Sjögren's Syndrome
diagnoses.reason: This condition primarily causes dry eyes and dry mouth but can affect other parts of the body, leading to a broad range of symptoms including interstitial cystitis and systemic issues.

diagnoses.name: Multiple Sclerosis
diagnoses.reason: An autoimmune disease of the central nervous system that can cause a wide range of symptoms, including vision problems, and might indirectly lead to symptoms like urinary tract issues due to nerve damage.

diagnoses.name: Vasculitis
diagnoses.reason: Inflammation of the blood vessels that can cause a wide range of symptoms, including leukocytosis due to inflammation, and can indirectly affect other body systems leading to various symptoms.

diagnoses.name: Granulomatosis with Polyangiitis
diagnoses.reason: A form of vasculitis that can cause sinusitis, kidney problems, and lung issues, potentially leading to wheezing and other symptoms.

diagnoses.name: Behçet's Disease
diagnoses.reason: A rare disorder causing blood vessel inflammation throughout your body, leading to symptoms ranging from mouth sores to eye inflammation, and could potentially lead to urinary system issues.

diagnoses.name: Interstitial Lung Disease
diagnoses.reason: This encompasses a group of disorders that can lead to lung scarring, affecting oxygen exchange and causing symptoms like wheezing; it does not directly cause urinary or vision issues but might occur in a broader systemic disorder context that does.

diagnoses.name: Addison's Disease
diagnoses.reason: A disorder that occurs when your body produces insufficient amounts of certain hormones produced by your adrenal glands, leading to a range of symptoms including nausea and vomiting. Vision problems and other symptoms might be indirectly related or a part of an overlap syndrome.

diagnoses: Myeloproliferative disorders (e.g., Essential thrombocythemia, Polycythemia vera)
Infections (bacterial, viral or fungal infections can lead to these conditions as part of a systemic response)
Bone marrow infiltration or fibrosis (due to various causes including malignancy and myelofibrosis)
Blepharospasm (as part of a broader neurological condition)

symptoms: dyspnea with normal pulmonary function tests
diagnoses: Heart failure with preserved ejection fraction (HFpEF)
Acquired angioedema (associated with C1 inhibitor deficiency)
Chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD) - considering sleep apnea
Hepatitis (various forms including A, B, C, autoimmune)
Toxic reactions (such as to medications or toxins)

diagnoses.name: Ehlers-Danlos Syndrome
diagnoses.description: A group of disorders that affect connective tissues supporting the skin, bones, blood vessels, and many other organs and tissues. Hypermobility is one of the primary symptoms.

diagnoses.name: Sjögren's Syndrome
diagnoses.description: An immune system disorder characterized by dry eyes and dry mouth. It can also cause dysfunction in organs and the nervous system.

diagnoses.name: Primary Ovarian Insufficiency
diagnoses.description: Also known as premature ovarian failure, it involves a loss of normal function of your ovaries before the age of 40. One of its symptoms may include infertility.

diagnoses.name: Polycystic Ovary Syndrome (PCOS)
diagnoses.description: A hormonal disorder causing enlarged ovaries with small cysts on the outer edges. Symptoms can include menstrual irregularity, infertility, and signs of high levels of androgens such as pelvic pain.

diagnoses.name: Hyperthyroidism
diagnoses.description: The overproduction of a hormone by the thyroid which can accelerate the body's metabolism significantly, causing palpitations, weight loss, and infertility.

diagnoses.name: Rheumatoid Arthritis
diagnoses.description: A chronic inflammatory disorder affecting many joints, including those in the hands and feet. While not directly causing infertility, it can contribute to complications in pregnancy and overall health that might indirectly affect fertility.

diagnoses.name: Marfan Syndrome
diagnoses.description: An inherited disorder that affects connective tissue — the fibers that support and anchor your organs and other structures in your body. People with this syndrome tend to be tall and thin with long arms, legs, fingers, and toes. It can sometimes be associated with lens dislocation and cardiovascular abnormalities but does not directly cause infertility.

diagnoses.name: Lupus
diagnoses.description: A systemic autoimmune disease that occurs when your body's immune system attacks your own tissues and organs. Symptoms vary but can include fatigue, joint pain, rash, and fever. It may lead to organ damage or failure.

diagnoses.name: Graves' Disease
diagnoses.description: An autoimmune disorder that results in the overproduction of thyroid hormones (hyperthyroidism). Symptoms may include palpitations, unintended weight loss, and infertility.

diagnoses.name: Anxiety Disorders
diagnoses.description: Various disorders that involve excessive nervousness, fear, apprehension, and worry. These feelings can cause physical symptoms, such as palpitations and dry mouth. Anxiety doesn't directly cause infertility, but stress and anxiety can interfere with sexual function and fertility.

diagnoses.name: Diabetes Mellitus
diagnoses.reasoning: Glycemic lability is a common feature, and diabetes can exacerbate atherosclerosis.

diagnoses.name: Hereditary Hemorrhagic Telangiectasia (HHT)
diagnoses.reasoning: HHT, also known as Osler-Weber-Rendu syndrome, is characterized by the presence of multiple angiomata. It doesn't directly explain hypermobility, atherosclerosis, or oral pain but can be associated with systemic manifestations that might indirectly relate.

diagnoses.name: Ehlers-Danlos Syndromes (EDS)
diagnoses.reasoning: A group of disorders that affect connective tissue, leading to hypermobility. Some types can involve vascular issues, potentially linking to oral pain and atherosclerosis.

diagnoses.name: Marfan Syndrome
diagnoses.reasoning: It is a connective tissue disorder that can cause hypermobility and has cardiovascular complications that could be linked to atherosclerosis.

diagnoses.name: Vascular Ehlers-Danlos Syndrome
diagnoses.reasoning: This type of EDS is particularly associated with severe vascular manifestations, which can contribute to atherosclerosis. Hypermobility and oral issues are common.

diagnoses.name: Lysosomal Acid Lipase Deficiency
diagnoses.reasoning: Though primarily affecting lipid metabolism, it can lead to vascular disease and atherosclerosis at a young age.

diagnoses.name: Chronic Periodontitis
diagnoses.reasoning: This is a potential cause for oral pain. It is associated with systemic inflammation and could contribute to or exacerbate atherosclerosis. It doesn't explain glycemic lability, angiomata, or hypermobility, though.

diagnoses.name: Glycogen Storage Disease
diagnoses.reasoning: Some types might present glycemic lability due to improper glucose storage and use, potentially associating with atherosclerosis due to metabolic disturbances. However, a direct correlation with angiomata, hypermobility, or oral pain would be less common.

diagnoses.name: Loeys-Dietz Syndrome
diagnoses.reasoning: A connective tissue disorder that affects the cardiovascular system, potentially causing atherosclerosis. It also features hypermobility.

diagnoses.name: Peutz-Jeghers Syndrome
diagnoses.reasoning: Characterized by the development of benign polyps in the gastrointestinal tract and pigmented spots on the skin and mucous membranes, including the lips and oral cavity which could relate to oral pain. Not directly associated with glycemic lability, hypermobility, or atherosclerosis, but it indicates systemic disease.

diagnoses: Vitamin Deficiency (e.g., Vitamin B12, Vitamin D)
Drug Reaction with Eosinophilia and Systemic Symptoms (DRESS) Syndrome

diagnoses.name: Systemic Lupus Erythematosus
diagnoses.description: A chronic autoimmune disease that can cause inflammation and pain in any part of your body. It's characterized by flares and remissions and can affect the joints, skin, brain, lungs, kidneys, and blood vessels, potentially leading to widespread inflammation and tissue damage in the affected organ.

diagnoses.name: Rheumatoid Arthritis
diagnoses.description: A chronic inflammatory disorder affecting many joints, including those in the hands and feet. It can cause bone erosion and joint deformity. Fatigue and sleep disturbances are common symptoms.

diagnoses.name: Fibromyalgia
diagnoses.description: A disorder characterized by widespread musculoskeletal pain accompanied by fatigue, sleep, memory and mood issues. It can lead to sensitivity to pain and may coexist with conditions such as irritable bowel syndrome and migraines.

diagnoses.name: Multiple Myeloma
diagnoses.description: A cancer that forms in a type of white blood cell called a plasma cell. Plasma cells help you fight infections by making antibodies that recognize and attack germs. Multiple myeloma causes cancer cells to accumulate in the bone marrow, where they crowd out healthy blood cells. Symptoms may include bone pain and fatigue.

diagnoses.name: Chronic Fatigue Syndrome
diagnoses.description: A complex disorder characterized by extreme fatigue that can't be explained by any underlying medical condition. The fatigue worsens with physical or mental activity, but doesn't improve with rest.

diagnoses.name: Leukemia
diagnoses.description: Cancer of the body's blood-forming tissues, including the bone marrow and the lymphatic system. It usually involves the white blood cells. The body produces abnormal white blood cells, which don't function properly. Symptoms include bone pain and fatigue.

diagnoses.name: Hypothyroidism
diagnoses.description: A condition in which your thyroid gland doesn't produce enough of certain crucial hormones. Hypothyroidism's symptoms may include fatigue, weight gain, and muscle weakness, often accompanied by joint pain.

diagnoses.name: Anemia
diagnoses.description: A condition in which you lack enough healthy red blood cells to carry adequate oxygen to your body's tissues. Having anemia might cause fatigue and weakness. Conditions like vitamin B12 deficiency or chronic diseases can cause anemia.

diagnoses.name: Hodgkin's Lymphoma
diagnoses.description: A type of lymphoma, which is a cancer of the lymphatic system, part of the immune system. Cells in the lymphatic system grow abnormally and may spread beyond it. Hodgkin's lymphoma is marked by the presence of a type of cell called the Reed-Sternberg cell.

diagnoses.name: Polymyalgia Rheumatica
diagnoses.description: An inflammatory disorder causing muscle pain and stiffness, especially in the shoulders. Symptoms of polymyalgia rheumatica can severely affect sleep and physical activity. It usually affects people older than 65.

diagnoses: Allergic conditions (e.g., allergic rhinitis for post-nasal drip)
Psychiatric conditions (attention deficit could be part of ADHD)
Angioedema as a manifestation of an allergic reaction
Inflammatory bowel disease (Crohn's disease, Ulcerative colitis)
Inflammatory Bowel Disease (Crohn's Disease, Ulcerative Colitis)
Chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD) exacerbation with allergic components

diagnoses.name: Anaphylaxis
diagnoses.description: A severe, life-threatening allergic reaction that can occur suddenly after exposure to an allergen. Symptoms can include hives, angioedema, difficulty breathing, abdominal cramps, and a sudden drop in blood pressure leading to syncope.

diagnoses.name: Hereditary Angioedema
diagnoses.description: A genetic disorder that causes episodes of severe swelling (angioedema), often accompanied by abdominal cramping, and in some cases, hives. It does not typically involve hives and rhinorrhea.

diagnoses.name: Allergic Rhinitis
diagnoses.description: An allergic response causing symptoms such as rhinorrhea, sneezing, and sometimes accompanied by hives and angioedema.

diagnoses.name: Urticaria (Hives)
diagnoses.description: An outbreak of swollen, pale red bumps or plaques on the skin. Can be accompanied by angioedema, and in severe cases, may lead to anaphylactic reactions including abdominal cramps and syncope.

diagnoses.name: Mast Cell Activation Syndrome
diagnoses.description: A condition caused by inappropriate activation of mast cells leading to a release of numerous mediators resulting in a wide range of symptoms including rhinorrhea, angioedema, abdominal cramps, and hives.

diagnoses.name: Food Allergy
diagnoses.description: An adverse immune response to food proteins causing a variety of symptoms, which can include abdominal cramps, hives, angioedema, and in severe cases, anaphylaxis leading to syncope.

diagnoses.name: Drug Allergy
diagnoses.description: An immune system reaction to a drug that can manifest in several ways, including hives, angioedema, abdominal cramps, and in extreme cases, anaphylaxis with rhinorrhea and syncope.

diagnoses.name: Insect Sting Allergy
diagnoses.description: An allergic reaction to the venom from a sting. Severe reactions can lead to anaphylaxis, presenting with symptoms such as hives, angioedema, abdominal cramps, and syncope.

diagnoses.name: Latex Allergy
diagnoses.description: An allergic response to natural rubber latex, symptoms of which can range from hives and angioedema to abdominal cramps, and in rare cases anaphylaxis resulting in syncope.

diagnoses.name: Systemic Lupus Erythematosus
diagnoses.description: A chronic autoimmune disease that can cause a wide range of symptoms, including rash (which could be confused with hives), abdominal cramps, and in rare cases, anaphylactic reactions.

diagnoses: Inflammatory Bowel Disease (Crohn's disease and Ulcerative Colitis)
Drug reaction with eosinophilia and systemic symptoms (DRESS) syndrome

diagnoses.name: Autonomic Neuropathy
diagnoses.description: A group of symptoms caused by damage to nerves that regulate nonvoluntary body functions, including heart rate, blood pressure, and sweating. It can lead to hypotension, incontinence, and potentially syncope due to sudden drops in blood pressure.

diagnoses.name: Diabetes Mellitus
diagnoses.description: A disorder of metabolism where the body is unable to properly use glucose from the blood, leading to high blood sugar. Over time, it can cause damage to various body systems, potentially leading to autonomic neuropathy, which can manifest as hypotension, incontinence, and other symptoms.

diagnoses.name: Multiple System Atrophy
diagnoses.description: A rare, degenerative neurological disorder affecting your body's involuntary functions, including blood pressure, breathing, digestive system, and motor control; may result in incontinence, syncope, and hypotension.

diagnoses.name: Parkinson's Disease
diagnoses.description: A neurodegenerative disorder that affects predominately dopamine-producing neurons in a specific area of the brain. Symptoms can include autonomic dysfunction, leading to incontinence, hypotension, and possibly syncope.

diagnoses.name: Primary Biliary Cirrhosis
diagnoses.description: A chronic disease that slowly destroys the bile ducts within the liver. It may lead to intractable pruritus. Autonomic neuropathy associated with this condition could explain syncope and hypotension.

diagnoses.name: Chronic Kidney Disease
diagnoses.description: A long-term condition where the kidneys do not work effectively. It can lead to hypertension, but in cases with severe fluid and electrolyte imbalances, hypotension and syncope can occur. Uremia can cause pruritus.

diagnoses.name: Addison's Disease
diagnoses.description: A disorder that occurs when the adrenal glands do not produce enough of their hormones. Hypotension and syncope are common due to the lack of aldosterone. Skin hyperpigmentation can sometimes be mistaken for generalized pruritus.

diagnoses.name: Guillain-Barre Syndrome
diagnoses.description: A rare disorder in which the body's immune system attacks the nerves. Initial symptoms can include weakness and tingling in the extremities. It can progress to affect autonomic functions leading to hypotension, incontinence, and possibly syncope.

diagnoses.name: Anaphylaxis
diagnoses.description: An acute and potentially lethal allergic reaction leading to hypotension, pruritus (due to histamine release), rhinorrhea, and potentially syncope if severe enough.

diagnoses.name: Medication Side Effects
diagnoses.description: Various medications can have side effects leading to the symptoms described. For example, antihypertensives can cause hypotension; some medications can induce syncope; others can cause incontinence or pruritus as side effects.

diagnoses.name: Stroke
diagnoses.description: A stroke occurs when the blood supply to part of the brain is interrupted or reduced, preventing brain tissue from getting oxygen and nutrients. Brain cells begin to die in minutes. Symptoms can include sudden numbness, weakness, especially on one side of the body, severe headache, confusion, trouble speaking or understanding speech, and visual problems.

diagnoses.name: Migraine with aura
diagnoses.description: A migraine with aura is a severe headache accompanied by visual disturbances (scotoma) and other neurological symptoms such as sensory disturbances including tingling and numbness. These symptoms typically precede the headache phase.

diagnoses.name: Transient Ischemic Attack (TIA)
diagnoses.description: Often called a mini-stroke, a transient ischemic attack is a brief, temporary disruption of blood supply to part of the brain, spinal cord, or retina, causing stroke-like symptoms such as paralysis, aphasia, and visual disturbances but usually lasting only a few minutes to an hour without causing permanent damage.

diagnoses.name: Brain tumor
diagnoses.description: A brain tumor can be either non-cancerous (benign) or cancerous (malignant), depending on the growth. Tumors can cause a wide range of symptoms including headaches, seizures, problems with vision (scotomas), weakness, numbness, and difficulties with speech (aphasia), depending on the tumor's location.

diagnoses.name: Multiple sclerosis
diagnoses.description: An autoimmune disease in which the immune system attacks the protective sheath (myelin) that covers nerve fibers, causing communication problems between the brain and the rest of the body. Symptoms can include numbness, weakness, balance and coordination issues, and speech disturbances including aphasia.

diagnoses.name: Brain abscess
diagnoses.description: A brain abscess is a collection of pus, immune cells, and other material in the brain, usually from a bacterial or fungal infection. Symptoms can include headache, fever, nausea, vomiting, speech problems like aphasia, and visual disturbances, among others.

diagnoses.name: Encephalitis
diagnoses.description: Inflammation of the brain, often due to infection. Symptoms can include headache, fever, confusion, a stiff neck, and weakness, which might progress to severe neurological issues such as aphasia and seizures.

diagnoses.name: Meningitis
diagnoses.description: An infection of the protective membranes covering the brain and spinal cord, known as the meninges. It can cause severe headache, fever, stiffness of the neck, confusion, nausea, and sensitivity to light. If it affects the brain, it could lead to weakness, numbness, and speech problems.

diagnoses.name: Cerebral aneurysm
diagnoses.description: A bulge or ballooning in a blood vessel in the brain that can leak or rupture, causing bleeding into the brain (hemorrhagic stroke). Symptoms might include a sudden, severe headache, double vision, nausea, confusion, and problems related to specific areas of the brain such as weakness or numbness.

diagnoses.name: Primary angiitis of the central nervous system
diagnoses.description: A rare disorder involving inflammation of the blood vessels in the brain and spinal cord, leading to various neurological problems including headaches, confusion, speech difficulties, and potential sensory problems such as numbness or weakness.

diagnoses: Toxic ingestion (e.g., alcohol poisoning, toxic plants)

diagnoses.name: Migraine with Aura
diagnoses.description: A type of headache characterized by visual disturbances and other aura symptoms followed by a severe headache, often on one side of the head. Symptoms can include temporary vision loss, seeing zigzags or flashing lights, sensory changes, and speech disturbances.

diagnoses.name: Transient Ischemic Attack (TIA)
diagnoses.description: Often called a mini-stroke, a TIA is a brief period of cerebral dysfunction caused by a temporary disruption of blood supply to the brain, resulting in stroke-like symptoms that completely resolve within 24 hours.

diagnoses.name: Multiple Sclerosis
diagnoses.description: A chronic, typically progressive disease involving damage to the sheaths of nerve cells in the brain and spinal cord, symptoms may include numbness, impairment of speech and of muscular coordination, blurred vision, and severe fatigue.

diagnoses.name: Hemiplegic Migraine
diagnoses.description: A rare form of migraine where people experience weakness on one side of their body in addition to the migraine headache. Symptoms can mimic those of a stroke, such as temporary numbness, weakness, or paralysis on one side of the body.

diagnoses.name: Brain Tumor
diagnoses.description: Any intracranial tumor created by abnormal and uncontrolled cell division, either in the brain itself (primary), in the cranial nerves, in the brain envelopes, skull, pituitary, and pineal gland. Symptoms can include headaches, seizures, problem with vision, vomiting, and mental changes.

diagnoses.name: Migraine without Aura
diagnoses.description: Migraines typically present with self-limited, recurrent severe headache associated with autonomic symptoms. About two-thirds of cases are common migraines (without aura). These do not have the neurological phenomena that a migraine with an aura might have.

diagnoses.name: Stroke
diagnoses.description: A medical condition in which poor blood flow to the brain results in cell death. Symptoms can include weakness on one side of the body, trouble speaking, dizziness, vision problems, and headache.

diagnoses.name: Meningitis
diagnoses.description: An acute inflammation of the protective membranes covering the brain and spinal cord, known collectively as the meninges. Symptoms can include headache, fever, confusion, a stiff neck, and sensitivity to light.

diagnoses.name: Optic Neuritis
diagnoses.description: Inflammation of the optic nerve that can cause a sudden reduction in vision and, typically, pain upon moving the eye. Often associated with multiple sclerosis.

diagnoses.name: Giant Cell Arteritis
diagnoses.description: An inflammatory disease of blood vessels (most often large and medium arteries of the head) that can lead to a significant loss of vision and stroke. Symptoms include headache, jaw claudication, visual disturbances, and tender arteries over the temples.

diagnoses.name: Multiple Sclerosis
diagnoses.description: A chronic illness involving your central nervous system. The immune system attacks myelin, which is the protective layer around your nerves, leading to demyelination, which causes a range of symptoms including paresthesia, ataxia, and visual disturbances.

diagnoses.name: Migraine with Aura
diagnoses.description: Migraines are a type of headache characterized by intense pain. Migraine with aura includes visual disturbances such as scintillations and scotomas, and can also involve sensory phenomena such as numbness and paresthesias.

diagnoses.name: Transient Ischemic Attack (TIA)
diagnoses.description: Often referred to as a mini-stroke, a TIA is a temporary period of symptoms similar to those of a stroke. It can cause sudden numbness, weakness, especially on one side of the body, ataxia, and visual disturbances including scotomas.

diagnoses.name: Stroke
diagnoses.description: A stroke occurs when the blood supply to part of your brain is interrupted or reduced, preventing brain tissue from getting oxygen and nutrients. Symptoms can include numbness, paralysis, difficulty seeing, and trouble walking or staying balanced (ataxia).

diagnoses.name: Guillain-Barre Syndrome
diagnoses.description: An uncommon sickness where your body's immune system attacks your nerves. Weakness and tingling in your extremities are usually the first symptoms. It can lead to paralysis involving sensory deficits like numbness and also motor impairments like ataxia.

diagnoses.name: Diabetic Neuropathy
diagnoses.description: A type of nerve damage that can occur with diabetes. High blood sugar (glucose) can injure nerves throughout your body. Diabetic neuropathy most often damages nerves in your legs and feet, causing paresthesia, numbness, and sometimes problems with balance (ataxia).

diagnoses.name: Vitamin B12 Deficiency
diagnoses.description: Vitamin B12 is crucial for the production of red blood cells and affects the function of nerve cells. A deficiency can lead to nerve damage causing numbness, paresthesia in the hands and feet, and ataxia.

diagnoses.name: Lyme Disease
diagnoses.description: An infectious disease caused by Borrelia bacteria, spread by ticks. Early symptoms may include rash, fever, headache, and fatigue, while later stage symptoms include neurological disorders such as paresthesia, ataxia, and facial palsy.

diagnoses.name: Optic Neuritis
diagnoses.description: Inflammation of the optic nerve that can cause a sudden reduction of vision in the affected eye, pain with eye movement, and sometimes symptoms like a scotoma. While not a diagnosis, optic neuritis can be associated with conditions like multiple sclerosis.

diagnoses.name: Meningitis
diagnoses.description: An acute inflammation of the protective membranes covering the brain and spinal cord, known collectively as the meninges. Symptoms can include severe headache, fever, confusion, vomiting, and sometimes symptoms like numbness or weakness, indicating nerve involvement.
An autoimmune disease that affects the brain and spinal cord, causing a range of neurological symptoms.
A neurological condition characterized by intense headaches often accompanied by nausea, vomiting, and sensitivity to light.
Often called a mini-stroke, it can cause temporary symptoms similar to a stroke, including numbness and speech difficulties.
A condition where poor blood flow to the brain results in cell death, causing symptoms such as numbness and difficulty speaking.
An abnormal growth of cells within the brain, which can cause symptoms depending on the tumor's location.
An autoimmune disorder attacking the optic nerves and spinal cord, leading to vision loss and paralysis.
An inflammatory disease of blood vessels most commonly affecting the head, which can lead to sudden, permanent vision loss.
A type of motor neuron disease that causes the death of neurons controlling voluntary muscles.
A type of nerve damage that can occur with diabetes, leading to numbness and pain in the hands and feet.
Inflammation of the optic nerve, which can cause partial or complete loss of sight in the affected eye.

diagnoses: Gastroenteritis (if nausea and vomiting predominate and CNS symptoms are secondary)

diagnoses.name: Migraine with Aura
diagnoses.description: Migraines with aura are headaches accompanied by sensory disturbances that can include scintillation, scotoma, and numbness.

diagnoses.name: Transient Ischemic Attack (TIA)
diagnoses.description: Often called a mini-stroke, a TIA may cause sudden dysarthria, paralysis, numbness, or weakness, particularly on one side of the body.

diagnoses.name: Multiple Sclerosis (MS)
diagnoses.description: A disease of the central nervous system characterized by symptoms like numbness, paresthesia, and in some cases, visual disturbances like scotoma.

diagnoses.name: Stroke
diagnoses.description: A stroke may present with sudden numbness, weakness especially on one side of the body, trouble speaking or understanding speech (dysarthria), and visual problems like blindness in one eye or unspecified visual disturbances.

diagnoses.name: Epilepsy
diagnoses.description: In focal seizures, individuals might experience sensory disturbances such as paresthesia and visual phenomena like scintillations before the seizure.

diagnoses.name: Brain Tumor
diagnoses.description: Depending on its location, a brain tumor can cause a variety of neurological symptoms, including numbness, visual disturbances (scotoma), and difficulties with speech (dysarthria).

diagnoses.name: Migraine
diagnoses.description: Migraine is a common type of headache that may present with numbing or tingling (paresthesia), speech difficulties, and visual phenomena like scintillations and scotomas apart from headache.

diagnoses.name: Diabetic Peripheral Neuropathy
diagnoses.description: A complication of diabetes featuring symptoms of numbness and paresthesia in the extremities.

diagnoses.name: Optic Neuritis
diagnoses.description: Inflammation of the optic nerve that may cause visual disturbances including scotoma, and in some cases, pain during eye movement.

diagnoses.name: Lupus
diagnoses.description: Lupus is an autoimmune disease that can affect multiple systems including the nervous system, possibly leading to symptoms like numbness, paresthesia, and in severe cases, neurological disorders causing visual disturbances and speech difficulties.

diagnoses.name: Stroke
diagnoses.description: A medical condition where poor blood flow to the brain results in cell death. It can lead to symptoms like aphasia, and in some cases, parasthesia or scotoma.

diagnoses.name: Multiple Sclerosis (MS)
diagnoses.description: A chronic autoimmune disease affecting the central nervous system, leading to symptoms like dysphagia, scotoma, and parasthesia.

diagnoses.name: Migraine with Aura
diagnoses.description: A type of migraine that involves visual disturbances such as scotomas. It can also lead to sensory phenomena like parasthesia.

diagnoses.name: Brain Tumor
diagnoses.description: Abnormal cell growth within the brain that can cause a wide range of neurological symptoms depending on its location, including aphasia, tinnitus, and parasthesia.

diagnoses.name: Transient Ischemic Attack (TIA)
diagnoses.description: Often referred to as a 'mini-stroke,' this temporary blockage of blood flow to the brain can cause symptoms similar to a stroke, including aphasia and parasthesia.

diagnoses.name: Meniere's Disease
diagnoses.description: A disorder of the inner ear causing vertigo, hearing loss, and tinnitus. It usually affects only one ear.

diagnoses.name: Amyotrophic Lateral Sclerosis (ALS)
diagnoses.description: A fatal motor neuron disease causing loss of muscle control. In advanced stages, it can lead to dysphagia.

diagnoses.name: Acoustic Neuroma
diagnoses.description: A benign tumor on the cranial nerve that can lead to hearing loss and tinnitus.

diagnoses.name: Glioma
diagnoses.description: A type of tumor that occurs in the brain and spinal cord, potentially causing symptoms like aphasia and parasthesia, depending on its location.

diagnoses.name: Multiple System Atrophy (MSA)
diagnoses.description: A rare, progressive neurodegenerative disorder affecting the body's autonomic functions, as well as motor control, leading to a wide range of symptoms including dysphagia and parasthesia.

diagnoses.name: Migraine with Aura
diagnoses.description: A type of headache characterized by visual disturbances and other aura symptoms followed by a severe headache, often accompanied by nausea, vomiting, and sensitivity to light and sound.

diagnoses.name: Migraine without Aura
diagnoses.description: A neurological condition that can cause multiple symptoms including headaches, nausea, vomiting, and sensitivity to light and sound.

diagnoses.name: Cluster Headaches
diagnoses.description: Severe headaches that occur in clusters or cyclical patterns, often associated with eye watering, nasal congestion, or swelling on one side of the face.

diagnoses.name: Tension-type Headaches
diagnoses.description: The most common type of primary headache, characterized by a constant pressure or ache around the head, particularly at the temples or back of the head and neck.

diagnoses.name: Transient Ischemic Attack
diagnoses.description: Often called a mini-stroke, a transient ischemic attack (TIA) occurs when there's a temporary lack of blood flow to part of the brain, which may cause symptoms similar to a stroke.

diagnoses.name: Multiple Sclerosis
diagnoses.description: A disease in which the immune system eats away at the protective covering of nerves, causing symptoms that can include numbness, impairment of speech, and muscular coordination issues.

diagnoses.name: Epilepsy
diagnoses.description: A central nervous system disorder in which brain activity becomes abnormal, causing seizures or periods of unusual behavior, sensations, and sometimes loss of awareness.

diagnoses.name: Brain Tumor
diagnoses.description: A mass or growth of abnormal cells in the brain. Symptoms may include headaches, seizures, problem with vision, vomiting, and mental changes.

diagnoses.name: Hypertension
diagnoses.description: While primarily known as high blood pressure, it can lead to headaches, especially when severe and unmanaged.

diagnoses.name: Hypoglycemia
diagnoses.description: A condition caused by a very low level of blood sugar (glucose), which can result in headaches, dizziness, confusion, and weakness.

diagnoses.name: Stroke
diagnoses.description: A stroke occurs when the blood supply to part of your brain is interrupted or reduced, preventing brain tissue from getting oxygen and nutrients. Brain cells begin to die in minutes. A stroke is a medical emergency, and prompt treatment is crucial. Early action can reduce brain damage and other complications.

diagnoses.name: Brain tumor
diagnoses.description: Brain tumors can disrupt brain function, affecting speech, motor function, and cognition. Symptoms can include headaches, seizures, weakness, nausea, and language disturbances such as dysarthria and aphasia.

diagnoses.name: Multiple sclerosis
diagnoses.description: Multiple sclerosis is a potentially disabling disease of the brain and spinal cord (central nervous system). The immune system attacks the protective sheath (myelin) that covers nerve fibers, causing communication problems between your brain and the rest of your body. Symptoms can include fatigue, difficulty walking, weakness, and speech problems.

diagnoses.name: Amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (ALS)
diagnoses.description: ALS, also known as Lou Gehrig's disease, is a progressive neurodegenerative disease that affects nerve cells in the brain and the spinal cord. With voluntary muscle action progressively affected, patients in the later stages of the disease may become totally paralyzed. Early symptoms include muscle weakness and speech difficulties.

diagnoses.name: Guillain-Barre syndrome
diagnoses.description: Guillain-Barre syndrome is a rare disorder in which your body's immune system attacks your nerves. Weakness and tingling in your extremities are usually the first symptoms. These sensations can quickly spread, eventually paralyzing your whole body. It can also affect speech and swallowing.

diagnoses.name: Migraine
diagnoses.description: Migraine is a powerful headache that often happens with nausea, vomiting, and sensitivity to light. It can also cause speech disturbances like dysarthria or aphasia in a complex aura phase.

diagnoses.name: Transient ischemic attack (TIA)
diagnoses.description: Often called a mini-stroke, a transient ischemic attack is a brief, temporary disruption of blood supply to part of your brain. It can cause symptoms similar to a stroke, including dysarthria, weakness, and aphasia, but typically lasts only a few minutes and causes no permanent damage.

diagnoses.name: Meningitis
diagnoses.description: Meningitis is an inflammation of the fluid and membranes (meninges) surrounding your brain and spinal cord. The swelling from meningitis typically triggers symptoms such as headache, fever, and a stiff neck. It can also lead to nausea, weakness, and speech difficulties.

diagnoses.name: Myasthenia gravis
diagnoses.description: Myasthenia gravis is characterized by weakness and rapid fatigue of any of the muscles under your voluntary control. It is caused by a breakdown in the normal communication between nerves and muscles. There can be difficulty in speech (dysarthria), swallowing, and in severe cases, breathing.

diagnoses.name: Encephalitis
diagnoses.description: Encephalitis is inflammation of the brain. Viral infections are the most common cause of encephalitis. Symptoms can include headache, fever, confusion, drowsiness, and fatigue. More severe cases can result in seizures, muscle weakness, and speech or hearing problems.

diagnoses: Drug Reaction with Eosinophilia and Systemic Symptoms (DRESS)
Chronic Kidney Disease (CKD) secondary to glomerulonephritis
Schizophrenia (for psychosis, if not due to a general medical condition)
Lupus nephritis (for proteinuria as part of systemic lupus erythematosus)
Drug reaction with eosinophilia and systemic symptoms (DRESS syndrome)
Hepatitis B or C with cryoglobulinemia
Evans Syndrome (Autoimmune Hemolytic Anemia with Immune Thrombocytopenia)

diagnoses.name: Systemic Lupus Erythematosus (SLE)
diagnoses.description: A chronic autoimmune disease that can affect the skin, kidneys, blood cells, brain, heart, and lungs. Lupus can cause a variety of symptoms including rash (lichen planus-like lesions), hemolytic anemia, and kidney involvement (proteinuria).

diagnoses.name: Evan's Syndrome
diagnoses.description: A rare autoimmune disorder characterized by the combination of immune thrombocytopenia (ITP) and autoimmune hemolytic anemia (AIHA).

diagnoses.name: Mixed Connective Tissue Disease (MCTD)
diagnoses.description: An autoimmune disorder that may present with features of several connective tissue diseases including lupus, scleroderma, and polymyositis. Symptoms can include skin changes, anemia, and proteinuria.

diagnoses.name: Antiphospholipid Syndrome (APS)
diagnoses.description: An autoimmune disorder characterized by thrombosis and/or pregnancy morbidity in the presence of persistently elevated levels of antiphospholipid antibodies. It can present with thrombocytopenia and livedo reticularis, which might be confused with telangiectasia.

diagnoses.name: Scleroderma
diagnoses.description: A group of autoimmune diseases that cause skin and connective tissue to harden and tighten. Telangiectasias are common in scleroderma. It can also lead to kidney problems and blood disorders.

diagnoses.name: Paroxysmal Nocturnal Hemoglobinuria (PNH)
diagnoses.description: A rare, acquired, life-threatening disease of the blood characterized by hemolytic anemia, thrombosis, and peripheral blood cytopenias. Thrombocytopenia and hemolytic anemia are common.

diagnoses.name: Idiopathic Thrombocytopenic Purpura (ITP)
diagnoses.description: An autoimmune disorder characterized primarily by thrombocytopenia (low platelet count). While not directly linked to lichen planus, hemolytic anemia, telangiectasias, or proteinuria, these symptoms could possibly appear in complex cases or when ITP is part of a broader autoimmune condition.

diagnoses.name: Disseminated Intravascular Coagulation (DIC)
diagnoses.description: A condition affecting the blood's ability to clot and stop bleeding. Symptoms can include thrombocytopenia. DIC is typically secondary to another disease process.

diagnoses.name: Lymphoma
diagnoses.description: A type of blood cancer that occurs when lymphocytes (a type of white blood cell) grow uncontrollably. Can present with systemic symptoms such as anemia and can cause kidney damage (proteinuria).

diagnoses.name: Autoimmune Hepatitis
diagnoses.description: A chronic condition in which the body's immune system attacks liver cells, potentially leading to liver failure. Can present with other autoimmune manifestations like hemolytic anemia.

diagnoses.name: Systemic Lupus Erythematosus (SLE)
diagnoses.rationale: This autoimmune disease commonly presents with symptoms such as leukopenia (low white blood cell count), nasal and oral ulcers, proteinuria (presence of excess proteins in the urine, indicating kidney involvement), and sometimes, chilblains (painful inflammation of small blood vessels in response to cold or damp conditions).

diagnoses.name: Mixed Connective Tissue Disease (MCTD)
diagnoses.rationale: MCTD combines features of various connective tissue diseases, such as lupus, scleroderma, and polymyositis, and can present with leukopenia, nasal and oral ulcers, proteinuria, and chilblains, among other symptoms.

diagnoses.name: Behçet's Disease
diagnoses.rationale: Behçet's disease is known for causing oral and sometimes nasal ulcers, and less frequently, it may present with skin conditions like chilblains, proteinuria due to kidney involvement, and occasionally leukopenia.

diagnoses.name: Rheumatoid Arthritis (RA)
diagnoses.rationale: Although RA is primarily known for joint swelling and pain, it can also cause oral ulcers and has been associated with leukopenia. Proteinuria could be secondary to medications or renal complications related to RA.

diagnoses.name: Sjögren's Syndrome
diagnoses.rationale: Sjögren's syndrome typically manifests as dry eyes and dry mouth due to destruction of glands that produce tears and saliva, but it can also cause leukopenia and oral ulcers. Kidney involvement could lead to proteinuria.

diagnoses.name: Vasculitis
diagnoses.rationale: Vasculitis, an inflammation of blood vessels, can lead to symptoms like oral ulcers and proteinuria (due to kidney involvement). Some types may cause leukopenia and skin issues, including chilblains.

diagnoses.name: Lupus Nephritis
diagnoses.rationale: Lupus nephritis is a specific manifestation of SLE affecting the kidneys, leading to proteinuria. Patients could also experience leukopenia, and oral and nasal ulcers as part of their lupus symptoms.

diagnoses.name: Cryoglobulinemia
diagnoses.rationale: Cryoglobulinemia, especially mixed cryoglobulinemia, can present with vasculitis, leading to skin manifestations such as chilblains, and potentially causing proteinuria and leukopenia.

diagnoses.name: Polymyositis and Dermatomyositis
diagnoses.rationale: These inflammatory muscle diseases can occasionally cause skin issues resembling chilblains, leukopenia, oral ulcers, and in the case of dermatomyositis, a rash. Kidney involvement could lead to proteinuria.

diagnoses.name: Churg-Strauss Syndrome
diagnoses.rationale: Also known as eosinophilic granulomatosis with polyangiitis, it can cause vasculitis affecting various organs and potentially leading to symptoms such as nasal and oral ulcers, leukopenia, proteinuria, and skin manifestations that might resemble chilblains.

diagnoses: Infectious diseases (e.g., HIV, Hepatitis C associated cryoglobulinemia)
